content:
EDIT:
As mentioned by stepBack not having a test case for == 0 was causing the issue with 100% test cases and 66% on submit(also happen in my clash) i have edited this clash to include a test case(7) for this case

Nice clash, but your tests/validators are poorly defined.

In a Fastest mode clash people often try to skim over the description to gain an advantage. It's natural for people to expect that the inputs will be positive integers, and many won't notice the "Note" that warns about this.

If you write code that doesn't check for negative/zero inputs, then it gets 100% on the test cases but only 66% on the validators.

This is because the only tests/validators that really check this are "Tricky small data" (V1) and "Tricky negative data" (V3). The corresponding test cases will pass, because "Small data" is >0 and "Negative data" is "-131" which leads to a "NO" answer anyway.

It would be good to add a test case that has a and b equal to one another, and an even negative number or 0, so that it gives clashers a chance to debug their code before submitting.

4/8 players in my clash got caught by this issue, including me: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/35783493736cbe64463cbed74beb70cfcf7003f

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice game for quick clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice game for quick clash or code golf

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice, good tricky test case

Goal
* Suggest to delete "distinguish whether the rectangle is a special square or not" in the last sentence to avoid repetition.

* Please add "Note: A rectangle whose sides are 0 is not a special square."

Having a  = b = 0 in the validator can give the players a nasty surprise, hence I suggest to add the note.

Input
* The description is wrong. There are two lines, not one line. Please use the following instead:

<<Line 1>>: An integer [[a]] for one side of the rectangle
<<Line 2>>: An integer [[b]] for the other side of the rectangle

Thanks.
Thanks for your feedback. I fixed all of that.
same thing happened to my group I've added a new test case to resolve these issues

The only issue now is that most of the tests/validators have "NO" as the answer (8/14), so a simple solution of `print("NO")` can get 57%.

It's not a big deal, but might warrant adding at least one extra pair of tests that doesn't give "NO" as the answer, when the original author reads this.
